ElementDescription: The NDAR Global Unique Identifier (GUID) for research subject
Subject ID how it's defined in lab/project
Date on which the interview/genetic test/sampling/imaging/biospecimen was completed. MM/DD/YYYY
Age in months at the time of the interview/test/sampling/imaging.
Notes: Age is rounded to chronological month. If the research participant is 15-days-old at time of interview, the appropriate value would be 0 months. If the participant is 16-days-old, the value would be 1 month.

ElementDescription: Sex of subject at birth
Notes: M = Male; F = Female; O=Other; NR = Not reported

ElementDescription: Restricted Affect
Notes: 1= The patient has a spontaneous and widely ranging display of affect; 2= A decrease in affect displayed so mild that it is not confidently considered pathological; 3= A moderate decrease of affect displayed in relation to many topics, or a severe decrease in relation to some topics.; 4= A severe decrease of affect displayed in relation to many topics, or a very severe decrease in relation to some topics; 5=  A very severe decrease of affect displayed in relation to many topics.

ElementDescription: Diminished Emotional Range
Notes: 1= No diminution of emotional variety or intensity; 2= A questionable decrease in variety or intensity of emotions of such mild severity that it is not confidently considered pathological; 3= A moderate decrease in variety or intensity of emotions in relation to many activities, or a severe decrease in relation to some activities; 4= A severe decrease in variety or intensity of emotions in relation to many activities, or a very severe decrease in relation to some activities; 5= A very severe decrease in variety or intensity of emotions in relation to many activities

ElementDescription: Poverty of Speech
Notes: 1= Speech normal in quantity of speech and amount of information conveyed; 2= A decrease in the quantity of speech or the amount of information conveyed by speech that is so mild that it is not confidently considered pathological; 3= A moderate decrease in the quantity of speech or the amount of information conveyed in relation to many topics, or a severe decrease in relation to some topics; 4=  A severe decrease in the quantity of speech or the amount of information conveyed in relation to many topics, or a very severe decrease in relation to some topics; 5= A very severe decrease in the quantity of speech or the amount of information conveyed in relation to many topics.

ElementDescription: Curbing of Interest
Notes: 1= A normal amount of interest in the world: either a wide range of interests or intense involvement in a narrow range of interests; 2= A decrease in the range or intensity of interests that is so mild that it is not confidently considered pathological; 3= A moderate decrease of range or intensity of interests; 4= A severe decrease of range or intensity of interests; 5= A very severe decrease of range or intensity of interests.

ElementDescription: Diminished Sense of Purpose
Notes: 1= Normal motivation and goal-directed activity displayed either in a relatively wide range of areas, or intensely in a narrow range; 2=  A decrease in motivation and goal-directed activity that is so mild that it is not confidently considered pathological; 3= A moderate decrease in range or intensity of motivation and goal-directed activity; 4= A severe decrease in range or intensity of motivation and goal-directed activity; 5= A very severe decrease in range or intensity of motivation and goal-directed activity

ElementDescription: Diminished Social Drive
Notes: 1= Spontaneous expression of social drive in a relatively wide range of situations; 2=  A decrease in social drive that is so mild that it is not confidently considered pathological; 3= A moderate decrease of social drive;  4= A severe decrease of social drive; 5= A very severe decrease of social drive

ElementDescription: Symptom Endorsed: Restricted Affect
Symptom Endorsed: Diminished Emotional Range
Symptom Endorsed: Poverty of Speech
Symptom Endorsed: Curbing of Interest
Symptom Endorsed: Diminished Sense of Purpose
Symptom Endorsed: Diminished Social Drive

Some combination of two or more of the negative symptoms listed above have been present for the preceding 12 months and were always present during periods of clinical stability (including chronic psychotic states).
The negative symptoms above are primary, i.e., not secondary to factors other and the disease process. Such factors include: Anxiety
The negative symptoms above are primary, i.e., not secondary to factors other and the disease process. Such factors include: Drug Effect
The negative symptoms above are primary, i.e., not secondary to factors other and the disease process. Such factors include: Suspiciousness (and other psychotic symptoms)
The negative symptoms above are primary, i.e., not secondary to factors other and the disease process. Such factors include: Mental Retardation
The negative symptoms above are primary, i.e., not secondary to factors other and the disease process. Such factors include: Depression
The patient meets DSM criteria of schizophrenia
